newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Uganda urges code of conduct for multinationals.
newsitem.headline: Uganda urges code of conduct for multinationals.

text.p: Uganda called on Monday for a legally binding international code of conduct to regulate the activities and influence of transnational corporations.

In a speech to the U.N. General Assembly, Ugandan First Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Eriya Kategaya said the increasing role of those corporations in world trade and in the flow of private capital had inordinately enhanced their control over resources and the transfer of technology and know-how in developing countries.
"In some cases, this control is beyond the capacity of many developing countries to check," he said.

"As the influence of these corporations grows with globalization, there is urgent need to elaborate and adopt an effective and legally binding international code of conduct to regulate the activities and influence of transnational corporations," Kategaya said.
He also lamented what he called the "increasing trend towards unfair trading practices and conflicts" in international trade.

"We are witnessing situations where developing countries are pushed to open up their markets, ostensibly to advance free trade and competition, while at the same time developed countries practice managed trade and limit access to some export products from developing countries."
He said the establishment in 1994 of the World Trade Organization (WTO) as a custodian and guardian of a rules-based mulitlateral trading system was a positive development.
